Based on the mechanism shown in figure. Drug X is likely to be:
All of the following are immune check point inhibitors except ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cetuximab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Avelumab, atezolizumab, and durvalumab are all programmed death ligand-1 (PD-L1) inhibitors that work by blocking the interaction between PD-L1 and its receptor, PD-1, on T cells. This helps to activate the immune system and attack cancer cells.
  • • Cetuximab, on the other hand, is a monoclonal antibody that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) on cancer cells. It does not inhibit PD-L1 and does not work through the same mechanism as PD-L1 inhibitors.
  • • Immune Check Point inhibitors
  • • Immune Check Point inhibitors

Trimetazidine is a drug approved for treatment of angina pectoris. Its mechanism of action is assumed to be?

A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a fever, headache, and muscle aches. He reports a recent camping trip in a rural area where he was exposed to ticks. On examination, there is a characteristic eschar at the site of a tick bite, as well as regional lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, the healthcare provider suspects scrub typhus. What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Scrub typhus is an acute febrile illness caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi, which is transmitted to humans by the bite of infected chiggers. The clinical presentation of scrub typhus is characterized by fever, headache, muscle aches, and the presence of an eschar at the site of the chigger bite. Laboratory findings may include thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and leukocytosis. The drug of choice for the treatment of scrub typhus is doxycycline. Other antibiotics, such as azithromycin, chloramphenicol, and ciprofloxacin, may also be used to treat scrub typhus, but doxycycline is the preferred drug due to its effectiveness and low risk of adverse effects. Erythromycin, sulfonamides, and metronidazole are not recommended for the treatment of scrub typhus
  • • Scrub typhus is an acute febrile illness caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi, which is transmitted to humans by the bite of infected chiggers. The clinical presentation of scrub typhus is characterized by fever, headache, muscle aches, and the presence of an eschar at the site of the chigger bite. Laboratory findings may include thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and leukocytosis.
  • • The drug of choice for the treatment of scrub typhus is doxycycline. Other antibiotics, such as azithromycin, chloramphenicol, and ciprofloxacin, may also be used to treat scrub typhus, but doxycycline is the preferred drug due to its effectiveness and low risk of adverse effects.
  • • Erythromycin, sulfonamides, and metronidazole are not recommended for the treatment of scrub typhus

questions.text: Which of the following agents is available as a patch for once-daily use and is likely to provide steady drug levels to treat Alzheimer’s disease?
Angiotensin receptor blocker which blocks thromboxane A2 receptor is?

A 25-year-old male with schizophrenia was treated with haloperidol 5 mg once daily at bedtime, which was increased to 7.5 mg daily in the 2nd week and 10 mg daily in the 3rd week. His symptoms improved, but in the 5th week, his family reported that his restlessness had returned, and he kept pacing around in the room, though he was not aggressive. The patient also reported an uncontrollable urge to move around and difficulty in falling asleep. Which of the following drugs would be the best choice for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanations:
  • • The patient's symptoms suggest that he may be experiencing akathisia, a side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol. Akathisia is characterized by restlessness, an uncontrollable urge to move, and difficulty in sitting still.
  • • Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is often used to treat akathisia and could be an appropriate choice to address the patient's symptoms. Higher doses of haloperidol may exacerbate the patient's restlessness and are not recommended in this case. Valbenazine is used to treat tardive dyskinesia, a different movement disorder associated with long-term antipsychotic use. It is not indicated for treating akathisia. Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant used to treat muscle spasms and malignant hyperthermia. It is not used to treat akathisia.
  • • Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is often used to treat akathisia and could be an appropriate choice to address the patient's symptoms.
  • • Higher doses of haloperidol may exacerbate the patient's restlessness and are not recommended in this case.
  • • Valbenazine is used to treat tardive dyskinesia, a different movement disorder associated with long-term antipsychotic use. It is not indicated for treating akathisia.
  • • Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant used to treat muscle spasms and malignant hyperthermia. It is not used to treat akathisia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a fever, headache, and abdominal pain for the past five days. On examination, his temperature is 102°F (39°C), and he has tenderness in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen. Blood cultures are positive for Salmonella typhi. Which of the following drugs is NOT used in the treatment of enteric fever?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Amikacin.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Enteric fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi. The mainstay of treatment for enteric fever is antibiotic therapy, which is typically initiated based on the results of a blood culture. Commonly used antibiotics for the treatment of enteric fever include ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and other fluoroquinolones. Rifampicin is also effective in treating enteric fever and is often used in combination with other antibiotics. However, amikacin, which is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is not typically used in the treatment of enteric fever.
  • • Enteric fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi.
  • • The mainstay of treatment for enteric fever is antibiotic therapy, which is typically initiated based on the results of a blood culture.
  • • Commonly used antibiotics for the treatment of enteric fever include ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and other fluoroquinolones.
  • • Rifampicin is also effective in treating enteric fever and is often used in combination with other antibiotics.
  • • However, amikacin, which is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is not typically used in the treatment of enteric fever.
